instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3127: What is CD3127? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3127 was most likely referring to a CD3217.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message:
H,

I have an A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power that had liquid contacts, and the client has already done an ultra-sound (can't see any corrosion right now).
On the ampmetter only consumes 5V, and on F3000 i get 5V, continually oscillating from 0, to 3 to 5V).

Do you think that it may be the <CHIP>CD3127</CHIP>? As i don't have any, should i re-flow it, or should i check anything else?

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message:
Do you get steady 5V at F3000/1?
What about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message:
Hi,
No i don't. On F3000/1 i get oscillating 5V ~0V.
On <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> i get oscillating 12V ~3V
On  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  i get oscillating  0.0V to 0.2V

On first post i said the it consumes 5A but i meant that it puls only 5V and consumes 0,2A. Sorry...

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message: All USB-C ports with the same behavior?

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message: Yes, it only has 2 ports, and its the same on both.

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message:
In such case, USB-C area should be good.
Power cycles when the board tries to switch to 20V on USB-C input.
Something is bad on the secondary power supplies.

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> should be present even when you have only 5V at input.
Start there; diode mode?

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted. diodo mode = 0.0003V. I 'll try to inject power and ee if anything gets hot.

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message: I've injected 3.3V on  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> , got an consume of 0.227A, and the only thing that gets hot is the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. Do you know if i can take it from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board?

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message:
I already suppose that it couldn't. Just to make sure with the expert :-)
I can't find it anywhre. Not even in China. Do you know if it is already possiblle to buy those? Do you know where?

threads.title: A2150 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power
threads.message: Apart of scrap boards, no idea...
